title: How do you handle data consistency challenges in multi-cloud storage systems?

content:
A multi-cloud storage system refers to distributed storage across multiple cloud platforms, facing data consistency challenges, namely maintaining real-time synchronization and integrity of data across all nodes. Its importance lies in ensuring business continuity, avoiding conflicts, and it is applied in hybrid cloud, disaster recovery, and multi-region service scenarios.

It corely involves consistency models, such as eventual consistency which emphasizes overall synchronization and tolerates delays; components include clock synchronization protocols and conflict resolution mechanisms. Practical applications include e-commerce inventory management, which uses distributed databases to handle global user requests, improving system reliability and reducing the risk of data loss.

Processing strategies are step-by-step: prioritize choosing a consistency model, such as eventual consistency being stronger than weak modes; deploy middleware like Apache Kafka to synchronize changes; use Kubernetes to manage storage interfaces and monitoring tools. Typical scenarios include multi-cloud backup systems, and the business value is enhancing data credibility and supporting compliance requirements.
